articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7b5 in F (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Dominant 7b5 Chord in F (Shape: E)

The Dominant 7b5 chord is a four-note chord built from the 5th degree of the major scale and is often used in jazz and blues music to add tension and dissonance. This particular Dominant 7b5 chord is played in the key of F, utilizing the shape based on an E starting point.

## Notes and Intervals

- F (Root)
- A (Major 3rd)
- Bb (Diminished 5th)
- E (Minor 7th)

The intervals between these notes create a unique and slightly dissonant sound that can add flair to your chord progressions.

## Genre and Flavor

The Dominant 7b5 chord in F, played with the E shape, is commonly found in jazz music due to its ability to create tension and lead into resolving chords. It has a darker and more complex sound compared to standard dominant chords, making it a popular choice for musicians looking to add color to their compositions. 

## Songs

Here are three songs that feature the Dominant 7b5 chord in F (shape: E):
1. "Autumn Leaves" by Joseph Kosma
2. "Blue Monk" by Thelonious Monk
3. "So What" by Miles Davis
